1.0 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Cargill, Inc. owns and operates Cargill Food and Pharma Specialties, a wet corn milling facility in Hammond, Indiana which is subject to U.S. EPA regulations governing Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions at 40 CFR Part 68.  Subpart G of 40 CFR Part 68 requires that a Risk Management Plan (RMP) be developed and submitted.  The RMP was developed using RMP*Submit 2004? published by U.S. EPA.  The RMP for the Cargill Food and Pharma Specialties Hammond plant identifies registration information, a toxic worst case scenario, toxic alternative release scenarios, a five-year accident history, prevention program information, emergency response program information and an executive summary that briefly describes and summarizes the plant?s risk management program.

1.1 Corporate Statement
Cargill?s policy is to conduct all business activities in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of our employees, contractors, customers and the public.

Environment.  Cargill will comply with all applicable laws and regulations; promote waste reduction, resource and property conservation and environmental protection; and train employees to be knowledgeable about all environmental matters relevant to their work.

Health and Safety.  Cargill will design, construct, maintain and operate facilities to protect human and physical resources; provide and require use of adequate protective equipment and measures, and insist that all work, however urgent, be done safely.

Food and Product Safety.  Cargill will provide safe food, feed, and materials for people and animals by using production, storage and transportation facilities that ensure the safety of products; choose suppliers that meet our requirements for safe raw materials and ingredients; and provide employees the training and resources they need to meet their individual responsibilities.

The Cargill Food and Pharma Specialties Hammond plant is des

igned, maintained and operated so as to minimize adverse impacts to its employees, local communities and the environment.  In order to insure the safe and effective response to an unlikely emergency in the workplace, the Hammond plant coordinates its safety and emergency response program with the local community?s emergency response personnel.  Plant management makes information available to the local community regarding the hazards and risks in operating the plant and the prevention techniques in place.  This includes insuring that all regulatory reporting requirements are met.

Plant management is fully informed as to the materials that are stored or used on-site and are aware of the possible risk associated with the material handling, storage, use, disposal or accidental release.  Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) for all materials utilized at the plant are maintained on-site.  The plant maintains inspection records and up-to-date procedures to insure the proper control of hazardous materials.  Procedures and systems are devised which include provisions for the periodic testing, review, and update of the emergency response programs. 

Employees are trained and periodically retrained in the methods of detection of hazardous material releases, the potential physical and health risks associated with the materials, and methods for protecting themselves, co-workers, and the public.  The plant investigates, corrects, and reports in writing all incidents involving hazardous materials having caused, or having the potential for causing, injury or loss.  

Adherence to these policies is essential in reducing the risk of accidental releases of hazardous materials and in decreasing the likelihood of adverse impacts to Cargill?s employees, the local communities and the environment.

1.2 Risk Management System
Cargill?s Hammond plant has developed a management system to oversee the implementation of the Risk Management Program in accordance with the requirements of 40 CFR Par

t 68.  The management system identifies job functions by responsibility level.
Facility Manager: Oversee facility operation; Facility spokesperson
Plant Superintendent: Review and approve facility safety policies/programs
Environmental Coordinator: Oversee implementation of RMP; Track new environmental regulations
Safety Director: Develop/review facility safety policies/programs; Develop facility PSM program procedures; Oversee contractor safety program; Track new safety regulations; Oversee compliance audits; Oversee facility safety training programs; Oversee implementation of PSM; Oversee MOC?s; Develop facility EAF; Review incident reports
Department Superintendents: Comply with Process Safety Management Program; Complete incident investigations; Follow-up to audit findings; Oversee and document maintenance; Complete management of change and pre-startup safety reviews; Department specific employee safety training; Comply with facility safety policies/programs; Develop operating procedures
Shift Supervisor: Incident Commander for emergency response; Plan and execute emergency drills

2.0 PROCESSES AND SUBSTANCES SUBJECT TO 40 CFR PART 68
2.1 Regulated Processes
The Hammond plant produces corn syrup and starches for food and non-food industries.  The raw materials and process chemicals utilized by the plant are delivered via truck and rail from external sources.  Access to the site by vendors, employees, and visitors is controlled by fencing and security checkpoints.  Propylene oxide is a chemical utilized in the wet corn milling process at the Hammond plant and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68.  The starch modification and cyclodextrin production process areas each use propylene oxide.  These are the only process areas at the plant that are subject to the above regulation, which addresses the potential off-site hazards of accidental releases.

The EPA Risk Management Regulation identifies three levels of requirements for industrial processes, denoted as Programs

1, 2 or 3. Program 1, which has minimal requirements, applies to facilities for which a worst-case release would not affect off-site receptors.  Program 3 applies to facilities with NAICS codes listed in the regulation or that are subject to Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management Standard (PSM).  Program 2 applies to all other facilities.  Cargill has elected to comply with Program 3, the program with the most rigorous RMP requirements.  The Program 3 accident prevention program encompasses the requirements of PSM.  Program 3 related information for the wastewater treatment plant and the starch modification and cyclodextrin production areas is included in the RMP.

2.2 Regulated Substances
Propylene oxide is delivered by railcar to a 29,835-gallon capacity storage tank located in the starch area.  At a maximum 85% capacity, the tank contains 207,000 pounds of propylene oxide.  From the storage tank, the propylene oxide is transferred to both the starch and cyclodextrin reaction area where it is added to any one of eight reactors in the starch production process and to a single reactor in the cyclodextrin production process. The starch modification and cyclodextrin production areas use propylene oxide as a reactant to generate water soluble products.

3.0 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
The Hammond plant has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements at 40 CFR Part 68.  The following sections summarize the elements of the accidental release prevention program in place at the Hammond plant.  Some elements, such as hot work permits, are included in the prevention program but are not specifically summarized below.  Furthermore, within each chemical system, there are safety features designed specifically for the process and chemical.  Examples of process specific controls include:  isolation valves, curbing and diking to contain releases, continuous process area monitoring, pressur

e relief devices, condensers and scrubbers for emission control, fire extinguishing systems, personal protective equipment, and trained emergency response personnel.

3.1 Process Safety Information
The Hammond plant maintains technical documents that are used to assist in accident prevention efforts.  This written safety information includes chemical properties, process descriptions and diagrams, equipment design information, and operational parameters.

3.2 Process Hazard Analysis  
The Hammond plant conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with processes are identified and controlled effectively.  The Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) analysis technique is primarily used to carry out these studies.  The HAZOP analysis is considered one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques.  A team of qualified personnel undertakes the studies with expertise in engineering, process operations, safety and maintenance.  The team findings are presented to on-site management for resolution.  Implementation of mitigation alternatives is based on a relative risk ranking system completed by the team.  The team findings are tracked until they are completed and appropriately documented. The HAZOP studies are revalidated at least once every five years.

3.3 Operating Procedures
The Hammond plant maintains written operating procedures for covered processes that address various modes of operations.  The operation modes include startup, normal operation, temporary operation, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process.  These procedures are referenced by experienced operators and are used as the basis for training new employees.  The procedures are regularly reviewed and updated as necessary. 

3.4 Training
The Hammond plant has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees operating the processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with the processes.  New employees receive init

ial training on the process basics and are then given on the-job supervision until they demonstrate the ability to work independently.  Refresher training is provided periodically to ensure operator skill and knowledge is retained.

3.5 Mechanical Integrity
The Hammond plant carries out documented maintenance checks on pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps, and emergency shutdown systems to ensure safe operating condition.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with training in proper maintenance practices.  These personnel are offered specialized training as needed.  Equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.  

3.6 Management of Change
The Hammond plant maintains written procedures to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel and other employees whose jobs are affected by a modification are informed of the changes and offered training to deal with the modification.

3.7 Pre-Startup Safety Review
The Hammond plant has written procedures that address the startup of new or modified processes.  The reviews are conducted to ensure that construction, equipment, procedures, and personnel are appropriately prepared for startup before operation begins.

3.8 Safe Work Practices
The Hammond plant has a number of safe work practice procedures in place to protect personnel and process equipment.  Procedures include sign-in and sign-out of maintenance and construction employees, as well as confined space entry, hot work, and lockout/tagout procedures.  These procedures are designed to ensure that proper precautions are taken and communication has occurred regarding the work and potential hazards.  

3.9 Employee Participation
The Hammond plant encourages employees to participate in all aspects of process safety management and accident prevention.  Employees are encouraged to express t

heir views concerning accident prevention and recommend facility improvements.  Employees have access to all the information created as part of the plant?s implementation of the accident prevention program and are invited to assist in the on-going update of the information.

3.10 Contractors
The Hammond plant uses contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities and to supplement regular workforce during peak maintenance periods.  Prior to selecting a contractor, an evaluation of safety performance is carried out.  Contractors are informed of any potential hazards around their work area and are instructed to report all incidents to their Cargill contact.  Contractors are also instructed in appropriate emergency response procedures.  

3.11 Incident Investigation
The Hammond plant promptly investigates any incident that resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in, a significant release of a regulated substance.  The investigations are undertaken to identify the parameters leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent a similar incident from recurring.  The reports are maintained for at least five years so that the reports can be reviewed in future hazard analysis studies.  

3.12 Compliance Audits
The Hammond plant conducts audits of the accident prevention program to determine the extent to which the procedures and practices that have been developed are being followed.  The audits are conducted at least once every three years.  Any findings are forwarded to on-site management so that prompt corrective action can take place.  Any corrective actions identified during the audit are tracked until completed.

4.0 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
In conjunction with the current RMP and PSM programs in place at the Hammond plant, there is a standard management practice that requires internal reporting of unusual events, including those in which any abnormal emission of regulated chemicals is observed or suspected. The incide

nt information is reviewed and a determination is made as to whether a reportable quantity on any chemical listed as requiring reports to regulatory authorities is involved.  If so, the appropriate authorities are notified.

Under 40 CFR Part 68.42, incidents during the five previous years that resulted in any of the following consequences are to be reported in the RMP.  These include death, injury or significant property damage on-site, and/or death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage off-site.  During the past five years, there have not been any accidents involving propylene oxide that qualify for reporting under 40 CFR Part 68.  

5.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The Hammond plant has established an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) to ensure appropriate steps are taken to protect the public health and the environment, as well as the safety of the plant employees.  The EAP is designed to address foreseeable emergency situations at the plant and to provide appropriate hazard and emergency preparedness information to employees, contractors, emergency response personnel, and the community.  Emergency situations can include fire, explosion, chemical release or spill, bomb threats, weather emergencies and other natural emergencies.  Cargill has developed procedures to be followed in the event of an emergency and a command structure to evaluate the emergency to determine the appropriate corrective action.  The Hammond plant has Emergency Response Personnel made up of plant employees from all areas of the plant that are trained in accordance with the requirements of the Emergency Awareness and Response Training Program.  Cargill will rely on the Hammond Fire Department, Hammond Police Department, Lake County Sheriff, and area ambulance/paramedic services for assistance as required to control and resolve emergencies.

Plant operation at the Hammond plant can present various types of potential hazards and Cargill recognizes the need t

o have a well-trained and prepared workforce to safely and effectively deal with emergency situations.  A preventative maintenance program to inspect and test emergency response equipment has been established.  Training programs including classroom time and drills have been established to ensure that Emergency Response Personnel can respond to emergencies.  Emergency response training exercises have included the Hammond Fire Department, area ambulance/paramedic services, and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  As specified in the EAP at the Hammond facility, representatives from the Hammond plant maintain contact with the LEPC.

6.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Cargill?s Hammond plant, under the recent RMP program, as well as its existing PSM and earlier SARA Title III Community Right-to-Know Act compliance programs, has organized its management system to effectively address foreseeable hazards and potential risks.  Both the advanced planning aspects of process design, operating procedures, and emergency preparedness, and the operational elements of system maintenance, safe operating practices and ongoing personnel training are necessary to support a continual improvement in facility safety.  These programs are documented so that information about safe handling of chemicals at the facility is readily available to all employees and in the event questions arise from public officials regarding potential risks to the community.  In addition, Cargill?s Hammond plant safety program incorporates continuous improvement through use of on-going evaluations of safety and programs.  The Hammond plant will continue to explore chemical substitution, process modifications and additional safety equipment that can reduce the risk for on and off site impact of potential releases.  All of these features of the RMP at the Hammond plant lead to operations that are safe today, but will be even safer tomorrow.
